Guides Language Reference Package Index

Package sockets

Version 0.1 by Theo Weidmann licensed under MIT

The sockets package allows you to open TCP sockets to servers or to create a TCP server socket yourself.

The following is a very basic example of opening a TCP socket to make an HTTP request and print the first 140 characters of the response.

🍦 socket 🍺 🔷📞🆕 🔤www.emojicode.org🔤 🔤80🔤
💬 socket 📇 🔤GET / HTTP/1.1❌r❌nHost: www.emojicode.org❌r❌n❌r❌n🔤

🍦 data 🍺 👂 socket 140
😀 🍺 🔡 data

At the time of writing this, the above code would return something similar to:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: GitHub.com
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Last-Modified: Sat, 29 Oct 2016 11:54:03 GMT
Access-Control-Al

Here we’ve an example of a minimal echo-server that listens on port 8728. The server simply sends back a copy of the data it received.

🍦 server 🍺 🔷🏄🆕 8728

🔁 👍 🍇
  🍦 clientSocket 🍺 🙋 server
  🔁 👍 🍇
    🍦 readData 👂 clientSocket 50
    🍊🍦 data readData 🍇
      💬 clientSocket data
    🍉
  🍉
🍉

Of course, the code above is very minimal and incomplete. For example, it can handle only one connection.

Classes

🏄
🏄 represents a socket that listens for clients on a given port.
📞
📞 represents a socket for communication between client and server.
